item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Fence Goes Up in Hong Kong
item.description: Two protest areas at Hong Kong government headquarters that were fenced off from the people, first in 1997 when China took the city back and then in 2014 when “Occupy” democracy demonstrations erupted, tell a tale of what is home.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Police officers at the Legislative Council building behind a fence decorated with yellow ribbons, which have become a symbol for people to show their solidarity with pro-democracy protesters occupying parts of Hong Kong.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Indie Rock Sound Reaches Central Park
item.description: New York played host last weekend to the first American edition of the Modern Sky Festival, which has established itself as one of the premier festivals for indie rock and pop in China.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: The Beijing-based band Second Hand Rose at the Modern Sky Festival in New York last Sunday.

item.title: No Syrians Are Allowed Into Jordan, Agencies Say
item.description: Fear of militants may have led to restrictions, analysts said, as the United Nations said it had not recorded any Syrian refugees entering Jordan in the past week.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Whirlwind Ascent of Houthi Rebels in Yemen Brings Relief and Trepidation
item.description: Overshadowed by the conflicts in Iraq and Syria, the rebel group’s stunning advance on Sana on Sept. 21 drew little notice.
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: U.S. Steps Up Fight to Block ISIS Volunteers
item.description: The Justice Department says it must focus on Americans traveling abroad because they could receive training, become radicalized, and then return to the United States to launch attacks.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:credit: Al Podgorski/Sun-Times Media, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mohammed Hamzah Khan’s parents. He is charged with trying to aid Islamic State.

item.title: Iguala Journal: In Case of Missing Students, Hillside Mass Graves Point to a Death March
item.description: Witnesses said that students from a teachers college were apprehended by police officers, killed and buried, but their accounts fuel further questions.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The badly burned bodies of 28 people were found last weekend in a mass grave on a hillside in the outskirts of the city.

item.title: Kenyan Leader Appears at His Hague Trial
item.description: Prosecutors said the case against Uhuru Kenyatta could not continue until the Kenyan government ended its obstruction and sent in evidence that was requested more than two years ago.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: In Kim Jong-un’s Absence, Rumors About Him Swirl in North Korea
item.description: American and South Korean officials say that while they think Mr. Kim might be ailing, there is no sign that there has been a coup.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Korea Central News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un in Pyongyang, North Korea, in July. He has not been seen in public since Sept. 3.

item.title: Newly Vigilant, U.S. Will Screen Fliers for Ebola
item.description: Federal health officials will require temperature checks for the first time at five major American airports for people arriving from the three West African countries hardest hit by the deadly Ebola virus.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:credit: Robert Stolarik for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman at John F. Kennedy International Airport, where starting Saturday, arrivals from Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea will have their temperature taken.

item.title: U.S. Focus on ISIS Frees Syria to Battle Rebels
item.description: Opponents of the Syrian government say the United States’ focus on the Islamic State has allowed government forces to renew its attacks on rebellious towns and neighborhoods.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: An American-led airstrike on Wednesday in Kobani, Syria, on the Turkish border. A Turkish official said the bombs did not stop the militants’ advance into town.

item.title: As Islamic State Nears Conquest of Syrian Town, U.S. Presses Turks
item.description: Officials warned that airstrikes alone would not be sufficient to protect the Syrian town of Kobani from the Islamic State fighters.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: President Obama, at the Pentagon on Wednesday, discussed the drive against the Islamic State.

item.title: Whirlwind Ascent of Houthi Rebels in Yemen Brings Relief and Trepidation
item.description: Overshadowed by the conflicts in Iraq and Syria, the rebel group’s stunning advance on Sana on Sept. 21 drew little notice.
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: European Leaders Scramble to Upgrade Response to Ebola Crisis
item.description: Europe has suffered a blow to its self-image of generosity, its efforts to contain Ebola overshadowed  by President Obama’s announcement that he was sending  3,000 troops to West Africa.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: American airmen set up tents on Wednesday for a 25-bed modular hospital to aid Liberian health workers infected with Ebola near Monrovia, Liberia.

item.title: Russia Seeks Sanctions Tit for Tat
item.description: The legislation aims to arm the Putin government with a way to compensate insider businessmen who the West had hoped would convince the Russian leader to reverse his course in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: One of four McDonald’s restaurants closed in Moscow in August, prompting concern about payback for Western sanctions.

item.title: Catalonia’s Leader Plays Down Talk of Secession Crisis
item.description: In an interview, Artur Mas indicated that if he could not hold a legal vote on separation from Spain, he would pursue a longer-term strategy for independence.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Estonians Embrace Life in a Digital World
item.description: With an microchip-embedded ID card, residents gain access to thousands of public and private services, including banking, medical records and even fishing licenses.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:credit: Fabian Weiss for The New York Times
item.media:description: Priit Heinla, an engineer, says he can't imagine doing things the old-fashioned way, like filing his taxes on paper or voting off-line.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Bill Maher Isn’t the Only One Who Misunderstands Religion
item.description: In Islam and other faiths, religion is more often a matter of culture and identity than beliefs and practices.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By REZA ASLAN

item.title: World Briefing: Thailand: Tactics of Police Questioned in Investigation of Tourists’ Murders
item.description: Amnesty International urged Thailand to investigate allegations that the police tortured two suspects who reportedly confessed to killing two British tourists on a southern island last month.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Lawsuit Against U.N. on the Spread of Cholera Epidemic in Haiti Advances
item.description: A federal judge in New York has agreed to hear oral arguments in a lawsuit filed against the United Nations by advocates for Haitian victims of the deadly cholera epidemic.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: Journalist Is Charged Over Report on Rumors About President
item.description: Prosecutors indicted a Japanese journalist on charges he defamed South Korea’s president by reporting rumors that she was absent for seven hours during the April ferry disaster because she was with a man.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Testimony Against Man Accused of Killing Wife on Honeymoon
item.description: A South African man convicted of murdering a woman on her honeymoon in Cape Town testified that the woman’s husband had organized the killing.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cave Paintings in Indonesia May Be Among the Oldest Known
item.description: The paintings of hands and animals in seven limestone caves on Sulawesi had previously been dismissed as no more than 10,000 years old.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD
item.media:description: Hand outlines found on a cave wall in Indonesia are at least 39,900 years old, researchers said.

item.title: ISIS Militants Shoot Down Iraqi Helicopter, Killing 2
item.description: The attack was the second time in less than a week that militants of the extremist group the Islamic State have shot down an Iraqi military helicopter.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KIRK SEMPLE and OMAR AL-JAWOSHY

item.title: Spain, Amid Protests, Destroys Dog of Ebola-Infected Nurse
item.description: Health authorities were concerned that the dog might have been infected and could have spread the disease, but the science surrounding the issue is unresolved.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER and PAM BELLUCK
item.media:description: María Teresa Romero Ramos with her dog Excalibur.

item.title: Officials Cite Error With Gloves in Spanish Case of Ebola
item.description: Spanish health officials began to explain Wednesday how an auxiliary nurse became the first Ebola case in Western Europe.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
